div.p: NARRATOR: Let's look at what happens to my perception of problems as I go through the Spiral.
NARRATOR: Social dependence makes problems seem normal. If everyone in our social group is experiencing the same problems, they don't seem unusual.
NARRATOR: Enabling removes consequences. When people around us make excuses for us, they prevent us from experiencing the pain of consequences.
NARRATOR: Psychological defenses trick us. As we use more and more defenses, it becomes more difficult for us to connect our problems to drinking or drugs.
NARRATOR: Memory blackouts erase memories of our problems, since they often happen at the same time.

NARRATOR: State dependent learning increasingly locks up emotions and things that we learn when making high-risk choices, so that we are not able to remember them or do them as well when we are sober.
NARRATOR: Impaired abstract thinking distorts cause and effect. This makes it hard for us to connect the problems to the alcohol or drug use.
NARRATOR: Withdrawal learning teaches us that using is the solution to, and not the cause of, our problems.
NARRATOR: When I am caught in the spiral, my drinking or drug use has so distorted my perception that I am not always aware of the true nature of the problem.
